answers.answer: Yes. Try the medicine!!! Your not giving up when your getting meds your moving on in your life.

There's a common stereotype that allows us to believe that if we end up taking meds for mental issues, 'we are nuts".  That couldn't be further from the truth.  Not getting all of the help that's available is nuts.Speak with your doctor.  He/she will have the right idea on where you need to go.

My answer is a resounding yes, do take anti-depressant medication.  It has saved my life.  I could not function without it.  Why suffer depression, when taking a pill can alleviate it?It is not giving in.  Don't you want to help yourself?  Why do you think it is giving in?  I am sure you would take a pill to ease the pain of a headache, or tummy ache.  Why not depression?  Why deny yourself help?
Taking a pill is only half of the solution.  Getting to the bottom of what it is that is depressing you is the other half.  It's a lot of work.... It is 100% doable.

You're not giving in, you have to realize that depression can be like any other medical condition requiring daily medication to control the symptoms.  For some, our depression occurs as a result of a past traumatic event which we never truly dealt with and have forgotten about.......it rears it's ugly head in the form of depression and/or anxiety.  With therapy we can determine if this is what is causing our depression, deal with it and move on...easing our depression.  For many, we never know why we're depressed, we just are and that's okay.  You're taking a big step in the right direction to feeling better, keep going so you can get your life back.  Wishing you all the best!

Some of us have depression for no known reason.  There is not always something that makes us depressed.  That is just not true.  I have had depression for many years, and it must be some imbalance in my brain, because anti-depressant pills alleviate it.  You give the impression there must be an underlying problem.Depression is like say, diabetes, we just have it.  It is part of us.  I urge Jessica to take anti-depressants.  She will kn ow if there is something in her life that triggered depression.  I do hope she sees a doctor and discusses this.

I do agree that with anxiety and depressive disorders, there isn't always some kind of deep rooted issue that needs discovered and explored.  With my panic disorder, that wasn't the case at all, and actually, I spent a lot more time TRYING to figure out the "why" instead of just addressing the issues at hand.That being said....therapy is still VERY helpful, even IF there isn't an underlying reason behind the depression.  Therapy can teach you tools to use to help yourself, beyond what the medication does.  Also, it's just so cathartic to "unload" all of those stessors on someone who has no stake in your life.  Therapy doesn't have to be about just finding some buried reason for our woes.I couldn't agree more with all of the wise posters here that getting help is not at ALL "giving in"....it's taking a hugely important step forward..its acknowledgeing that the issue is bigger that you, and that you need help getting through it.  With the amounts of medications on the market, and numerous kinds of therapy, there is just NO reason these days that a person should suffer needlessly with depression.  We know SO much more than we did about these kinds of disorders than we did even 20 years ago. The field is forever evolving and recognizing that a LOT of people suffer from one kind of disorder of another.  We live in an awfully stressful world, it only makes sense that there has been such a rise in the numbers of people afflicted.Do it, make that phone call to your doc...ask for a referral to a psychiatrist, who can properly diagnose you and start exploring treatment options with you.  Please come back and let us know how you're doing...we care.  You are among people who understand!  Good luck!

Hi everyone -Before taking any medication, speak to your doctor, and that includes natural or alternative treatments.  Several have side effects that can affect you (for example, some can increase your heart rate, which can be a problem for someone with a heart condition, or affect kidneys, etc.)dwt7let brings up an excellent point, as well - make sure to get a thorough check up, as sometimes something physical could be causing the problems.We want everyone to live happy, healthy lives, and sometimes medications are needed to do that.  It's not giving in to take an antidepressant any more than it is giving in to take insulin if you have diabetes, or allergy meds if you have allergies.Take care,Emily
